topic.title: History is made up.
topic.body:
Fomenko and New Chronology. Essentially history was altered during the christianization of Europe and the 30 years war. Every single supporting document of the official timeline is a copy made after the 30 years war.

The 30 years war was the real WW1. It involved every western country. In proportion to the total population at the time, the death toll (military and civilian) rivals that of WW1 and WW2.

Timeline Deathtoll:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3GBY51_item_201+type:image

Apart from physical artifacts, they could have made the context and history before that, anything they wanted.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Chronology_(Fomenko%29

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War

New Video Zite Needed
topic.body:
Hi, we need a new basic video site that will allow us to upload clips, and share them. 
Does anyone have any plans to do something like this? 

IFS has not had any work done in years
CopyKate is a slow disaster. 
We need something that actually works. 

It needs to be simple.

1579444197_1GGwcwi7tW4RZaAfG3xPR4JpoNE4A.body:
> [driud](#comment_27_18yZKKFySP5bvmNy14T9vgj3H99AC1PQkH): Ciekawy układ, strony; zawiera wszystko co potrzeba. Szkoda tylko że jest, w języku niewolników.                         Brak możliwości wyboru języka, wolnego i niezależnego.Wielka szkoda, chętnie bym ją propagował znajomym..Interesting layout, pages; contains everything you need. It is a pity that it is in the language of slaves. No language selection, free and independent.It's a pity, I'd like to propagate it to my friends

clone the zite and edit it so it reflects what you want. its all open source. the current developer went dark in 2017. if you make IFS better, I'll seed it.

1579558261_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: Only buy LG or Samsung original 18650 batteries. You can get them from Vape shops easily as most of the vape mods use them.

1579514127_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: Knowing how to access information is just as important as having the information. The reason why the old system of universities had a set curriculum was in order to rigorously change you into perpetuating that system of learning while keeping it among an elite occupier class. The internet has made universities obsolete. There is no reason to grant them authority over information. There is no reason why normal people cannot publish scientific papers or do research. My only advice would be to develop an alternative to Google, as Google is starting to censor dissenting information.

Dr. Tony Martin - The Jewish Onslaught (1993)
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3GBY51_item_317+type:video

Dr. Tony Martin - Jewish Involvement in the Slave Trade - Institute for Historical Review Talk - June 2002
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3GBY51_item_318+type:video

Dr Tony Martin - Alternative Forum Talk - November 8 2000
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3GBY51_item_319+type:video

Tony Martin - The Jewish Onslaught - Dispatches from the Wellesley Battlefront-The Majority Press (1993)
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3GBY51_item_320+type:book

Tony Martin (February 21, 1942 – January 17, 2013)[1] was a Trinidad-born professor of Africana Studies at Wellesley College. He retired in June 2007 as professor emeritus after 34 years teaching at the Africana Studies Department, where he was a founding member.

He was a lecturer and author of scholarly articles about Black History, primarily the Black Nationalist leader Marcus Garvey, and his written works and statements regarding Jewish involvement in the American slave trade, which echo allegations made by the Nation of Islam, have been a source of ongoing controversy.

Life and academic credentials
Born Anthony Martin in Port of Spain, Trinidad, he attended Tranquillity School, where he was a contemporary of Stokely Carmichael.[2] After secondary school Martin went to England to study law at Gray's Inn, London, where he was called to the Bar in 1966.[3][4]

Martin subsequently received a B.Sc. honours degree in economics at the University of Hull (1968). He taught briefly in Trinidad at the Cipriani Labour College and St. Mary's College, before moving to the United States in 1969 to pursue graduate studies in African History at Michigan State University, earning an M.A. and completing his Ph.D in 1973. His doctoral dissertation, on Marcus Garvey and the UNIA, would be the basis for the book he later published as Race First: The Ideological and Organizational Struggles of Marcus Garvey and the Universal Negro Improvement Association.[3]

Martin was founder and chair of the Africana Studies Department at Wellesley College, where he began teaching in 1973, became tenured in 1975, and became a full professor in 1979.[5] He also taught at the University of Michigan-Flint and was a visiting professor at the University of Minnesota, Brandeis University, Brown University, and Colorado College, and also spent a year as an honorary research fellow at the University of the West Indies, Trinidad.[6]

Martin was a prolific author of scholarly articles on many aspects of Black History and lectured all over the world. He received awards and honors from the American Philosophical Society, the Association for the Study of Classical African Civilizations and many others.[7]

Martin also wrote, compiled or edited 14 books, most recently Caribbean History: From Pre-Colonial Origins to the Present (2012) and Amy Ashwood Garvey: Pan-Africanist, Feminist and Mrs. Marcus Garvey No. 1, Or, A Tale of Two Amies (2007). He had been working on two further biographies of Trinidadian women, of Audrey Jeffers (who was his aunt)[8] and Kathleen Davis (also known as “Aunty Kay”).[9]

Martin died unexpectedly on January 17, 2013, aged 70, at Westshore Medical Hospital, Cocorite, Trinidad.

Research
Marcus Garvey
Martin was a prolific Garvey scholar - he was considered by some "the world's foremost authority on Marcus Garvey"[13] - one of his earliest works being Race First: The Ideological and Organizational Struggles of Marcus Garvey and the Universal Negro Improvement Association, published in 1976.

He wrote a number of other books about Garvey, including Marcus Garvey Hero: A First Biography (1983), African Fundamentalism: A Literary and Cultural Anthology of Garvey's Harlem Renaissance (1991), Literary Garveyism: Garvey, Black Arts and the Harlem Renaissance (1983), The Poetical Works of Marcus Garvey (1983), and The Pan-African Connection: From Slavery to Garvey and Beyond (1984).

He co-authored, with Wendy Ball, Rare Afro-Americana: A Reconstruction of the Adger Library (1981).

Controversies
Harassment of students
In October 1991, a Wellesley student, Michelle Plantec, while on hall duty, claimed that she saw Martin wandering in a female dorm in a restricted area, in violation of a rule requiring male guests to be escorted. When she asked him about his escort, Martin, she claims, responded using profanity, accused her of racism and bigotry, and positioned himself so as to physically intimidate her. Martin denied all these claims, and declared that a group of women "accosted him rudely, despite circumstances that in his view made the legitimacy of his presence obvious."[14]

In an interview with a campus newspaper, Plantec said: "I stopped him and said, 'Excuse me, sir, who are you with?' He looked at me and said, 'What do you mean?' I said, 'What Wellesley student are you with?' and at that point he exploded and called me a fucking bitch, a racist, and a bigot, among other things. ...After all this, he went back into his meeting and said the only reason I had stopped him was because he was black."[15]

Martin, in the same interview, agreed that there was an angry exchange, but denied that he used profanity. He also said he asked permission from the dormitory desk before going to the restroom. "Coming out of the restroom, I was rudely accosted by a group of women who were coming up the stairs behind me. ...I tried to ignore them for a short space of time. ... And eventually, when we got to the top of the stairs I became very annoyed, and expressed my annoyance to the people who were behind me."[15]

Lefkowitz controversy, Wellesley course controversy, and lawsuit
Mary Lefkowitz was a classics professor at Wellesley, who taught courses on ancient Greek culture. In a 1992 article for The New Republic, she challenged what she felt were ahistorical Afrocentric claims, such as the claim that Greek philosophy was plagiarized from African sources. Following publication of the New Republic piece, she and Martin became engaged in a heated disagreement, with Martin criticizing her in his department's Africana Studies Newsletter,[16] and she criticizing him in the Wall Street Journal, the Chronicle of Higher Education, The New Republic, and elsewhere.[17][18][19]

As this controversy progressed, Lefkowitz discovered that students in Martin's class were assigned a book called The Secret Relationship Between Blacks and Jews,[20] compiled by the Historical Research Department of the Nation of Islam. The book's thesis, is that Jews had a disproportionately large role in the black slave trade relative to their numbers. This thesis has since been condemned and refuted by mainstream historians including the American Historical Association.[21] Lefkowitz ignited a controversy over the book's inclusion on the curriculum, and the controversy made national headlines in the spring of 1993. NPR, the New York Times, the Boston Globe, and the Associated Press, among others, covered the story.[17][22]

In Martin's view,

In January 1993, I was minding my own business and teaching my Wellesley College survey course on African American History when a funny thing happened. The long arm of Jewish intolerance reached into my classroom. Unknown to me, three student officers of the Jewish Hillel organization (campus B'nai B'rith stablemates of the Anti-Defamation League), sat in on my class and remained for a single period only. Their purpose was to monitor my presentation. As one of them explained in a campus meeting later, Jewish students had noticed The Secret Relationship Between Blacks and Jews among my offerings in the school bookstore. The book documents the considerable Jewish involvement in the Transatlantic African Slave Trade, the dissemination of which knowledge they, as Jews, considered an "anti-Semitic" and most "hateful" act.[23]

One of Lefkowitz's responses to this controversy was an article in the September/October 1993 issue of Measure: University Centers for Rational Alternatives.[24] In this article Lefkowitz made several allegations which Martin deemed libellous. For instance she alleged that during the October 1991 incident discussed above, Martin had called a student "a white, fucking bitch" and that "the young woman fell down as a result of his onslaught, and Martin bent over to continue his rage at her." Martin initiated a libel suit.[15] [25] Martin had already sued several undergraduates for libel, as well as Wellesley College itself.[17] The dean of Wellesley College, Nancy Kolodny, declined to pay Lefkowitz's court costs. She reportedly said to Lefkowitz: "It's your problem. The college can't help you." In the end, the Anti-Defamation League provided for Lefkowitz's defense. Three other national Jewish organizations, the American Jewish Committee, the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Council for Public Affairs, provided assistance. The case went through six years of appeals and counter-appeals, and was finally dismissed.[26][27]

As the campus controversy wound down, Martin published a book telling his side of the story: The Jewish Onslaught: Despatches from the Wellesley Battlefront (1993).[19] (See section below.) Lefkowitz published her own views three years later in the book Not Out of Africa (Basic Books, 1996).[28] In 2008 she published another book, History Lesson: A Race Odyssey, giving her version of the story of the lawsuit and the controversy with Martin.[29]

Libel lawsuit against Counterpoint
In the wake of the 1993 controversy, Counterpoint, a joint MIT-Wellesley student publication, asked MIT student Avik Roy to write a "retrospective chronicling the controversy surrounding Martin since his arrival as associate professor in 1973." According to Roy, he was asked to write the article because the staff felt he would be less biased than a Wellesley student. The article by Roy was published in the fall 1993 issue of Counterpoint. It alleged that Martin "gained tenure within the Africana Studies department only after successfully suing the college for racial discrimination," and that this explained a reluctance on the part of the College to censure Martin. Martin sued Roy for libel. Roy refused to disclose the confidential sources of his information even after the case was brought to court. A Massachusetts Superior Court Judge found that a lawsuit by Martin against Wellesley had in fact occurred, but "well after his tenure, and thus could not have caused it." The suit in question was filed in 1987, and alleged racial discrimination over a merit increase. However, the 1991 libel suit was eventually dismissed, with the judge ruling that Martin did not meet his burden of proof on 4 out of 5 necessary components for proving libel. The judge found that the offending statement was "partly false, but substantially true," though inaccurate in its "implication of timing and causation." The judge agreed that Roy's conclusion, that fear of litigation would cause Wellesley to exercise "particular restraint" when dealing with Martin, "follows at least as strongly from the actual facts as it would from the erroneous version."[14][30]

The Jewish Onslaught
In 1993, Martin published The Jewish Onslaught: Despatches from the Wellesley Battlefront. It was praised by a number of reviewers. Molefi Asante of Temple University called the book the best polemic by an African since the 1829 classic, David Walker's Appeal.[31] Raymond Winbush of Vanderbilt University compared it to W. E. B. Du Bois' Souls of Black Folk.[32]

However, the Chair of Martin's department at Wellesley, Selwyn R. Cudjoe, labelled Martin's book "Gangsta history, meant to demean and to defame others and to bring them into disrepute, rather than to enlighten and to lead us to a more complex and sophisticated understanding of social phenomena. It ought to be labeled anti-Semitic."[33] The majority of the Wellesley faculty signed a statement condemning Martin's work "for its racial and ethnic stereotyping and for its anti-Semitism."[34]

Martin's book was also criticized in a statement by the president of Wellesley College:

[The book] gratuitously attacks individuals and groups at Wellesley College through innuendo and the application of racial and religious stereotype.... Despite Professor Martin's incendiary words, and his attempt to portray Wellesley College as a repressive institution bent on silencing him, we will continue to recognize his right to express himself.[35]

Martin and Henry Louis Gates, Jr.
Henry Louis Gates, Jr., Chair of the African and African American Studies Department and Director of the W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for African and African American Research at Harvard University, was critical of Martin's work, leading Martin to describe him as "Brer Gates" (see: Joel Chandler Harris) and to write:

"Whenever the other folks have wanted anybody to beat the rest of the race over the head with, Brer Gates has been on the scene, like an HNIC ["Head Nigger in Charge"] machine. They gave him an unprecedented full page op-ed in the New York Times to attack the Nation of Islam's Secret Relationship Between Blacks and Jews. This op-ed was actually typeset in the shape of a Star of David. There is no evidence that Gates even read the book, but he pulled together some platitudes attacking it anyway."[36]

Institute for Historical Review
In June 2002, Martin presented a talk entitled Tactics of Organized Jewry in Suppressing Free Speech[37][38] at the 14th IHR Conference sponsored by the Institute for Historical Review.[39]

Works
Race First: The Ideological and Organizational Struggles of Marcus Garvey and the Universal Negro Improvement Association, 1976, 421 pages (ISBN 0-912469-23-4)
Rare Afro-Americana: A Reconstruction of the Adjer Library (with Wendy Ball), 1981.
Marcus Garvey, Hero: A First Biography, 1983 (ISBN 978-0912469058).
Literary Garveyism: Garvey, Black Arts and the Harlem, 1983 (ISBN 978-0912469010)
The Poetical Works of Marcus Garvey (compiled and edited), 1983.
In Nobody's Backyard: The Grenada Revolution in Its Own Words, edited by Tony Martin with Dessima Williams. Vol. I, The Revolution at Home. Vol. II, Facing the World, 1984.
African Fundamentalism: A Literary and Cultural Anthology of Garvey's Harlem Renaissance, 1991 (ISBN 978-0912469096).
The Jewish Onslaught: Despatches from the Wellesley Battlefront, Dover, MA: The Majority Press, 1993 (ISBN 978-0912469300).
The Pan-African Connection: From Slavery to Garvey and Beyond (1983), 1998 (ISBN 978-0912469119).
The Progress of the African Race Since Emancipation and Prospects for the Future (pamphlet), Port of Spain: Emancipation Support Committee / Dover, MA: The Majority Press, 1998 (ISBN 0-912469-35-8).
Amy Ashwood Garvey, Pan-Africanist, Feminist and Mrs Marcus Garvey No. 1, Or, A Tale of Two Armies, 2007.
Caribbean History: From Pre-Colonial Origins to the Present, Pearson, 2012 (ISBN 978-0-13-220860-4).

Notes
 "Professor Tony Martin Dies at 70", Trinidad and Tobago News, January 17, 2013.
 Prof. Tony Martin, "Kwame Turé: Tribute to a Departed Pan-Africanist", USAfricaOnline.
 Christopher Carrico, "Insurgent Anthropologies: A Dialogue with Pan-African Historian Dr Tony Martin", August 8, 2010.
 "Anthony C. Martin, Ph.D. (History)", Faculty Emeritus, Wellesley College.
 The Majority Press website, accessed April 18, 2010.
 "Dr. Tony Martin, the Premier Scholar Of Marcus Garvey Has Died", Caribbean Events, February 8, 2013.
 Dr. Tony Martin's website, accessed April 18, 2010.
 "Martin, Professor Anthony", Death Notices, Trinidad & Tobago Guardian, January 24, 2013.
 Biographical notes, Michigan State University.
 Zahra Gordon, "Prof Tony Martin dies at 70", Trinidad & Tobago Guardian, January 19, 2013.
 "Professor Tony Martin Dies at 70", Trinicenter.com, January 17, 2012.
 "Celebrated Marcus Garvey Historian, Dr. Tony Martin, Dies in Trinidad", Atlanta Black Star, January 24, 2013.
 Camille Bethel, "Martin helped to liberate minds, says Kambon", Trinidad Express Newspapers, January 21, 2013.
 Zareena Hussain, "Counterpoint Writer Cleared in Libel Suit", The Tech (MIT), January 6, 1999. Accessed April 18, 2010.
 Hyun Soo Kim, "Wellesley professor accuses Counterpoint, writer of libel". The Tech (MIT), Volume 114, Issue 8, February 22, 1994. Accessed April 18, 2010.

 Nation of Islam, The Secret Relationship between Blacks and Jews. Chicago, IL: Nation of Islam, 1991.
 In response to this book, the American Historical Association issued a statement in 1995 declaring: "The AHA [...] condemns as false any statement alleging that Jews played a disproportionate role in the exploitation of slave labor or in the Atlantic slave trade." See American Historical Association, "AHA Council Issues Policy Resolution about Jews and the Slave Trade", Perspectives, March 1995, accessed April 18, 2010. See also Eli Faber, Jews, Slaves, and the Slave Trade: Setting the Record Straight (New York University Press, 1998). See also Herbert Klein's book review, Journal of Social History, Spring 2000.

 A journal published by Columbia University's Center for Rational Alternatives, founded in the wake of the student unrest of the late 1960s.

1583512099_17ThiaUZmUKD2nEKkvUN6iCvaa1F3.body:
We are looking for developers to implement new features in a fork of the project as the original Dev is mia. Help us build this into a central point of Zeronet for content.

Specifically, we are looking to implement the following features:
1. Automatic thumbnail generation for videos, images, documents and audio.
2. More advanced search functionality and filtering.
3. image, video and low res audio support in comments.
4. namecoin .bit address (we're holding off on this until we've forked)
5. cluster management settings ie. move content and channels between clusters.
6. local storage management
7. in browser document/book viewing for txt/doc/odf/pdf

If you have any ideas on how to improve the zite please let us know.

> [zeroseed](#comment_20_1CcmrTeqtuoQtUpuxBZ9wFZz1tPaBcKb1g): if you want to add thumbnails please make it optional and not the default choose because thumbnails can be a legal problem if it will show frame of illegal files. If you make thumbnails the default you will force all users to use TOR (and this will slow the entire network also for legal files)

Good point. A thumbnail toggle at the top, with it being off by default could be a good way to do it?

> [zeroseed](#comment_22_1CcmrTeqtuoQtUpuxBZ9wFZz1tPaBcKb1g): i see in my last test that my HD vid streams very fast with only 1 seed. There is a seedbox active managed by someone? The VPS that i'm using for seeding many zites on zeronet don't have enough disk space for big files, but maybe i can rent a dedicated server for this purpose (only legal files) [...]

thank you, please do that.

> [hagen](#comment_10_175PgC2m3jvdQtCdbDtSztPWbgeDguuuNX): I made a channel for rare videos of American philosopher-mystic Franklin Merrell-Wolff.He had lots of Buddhism style ideas. Arriving at them independently, he still help popularise them in America at a time when most americans hadn't heard of them.He does this all while still remaining intellectually rigorous and without falling into stupid new age nonsense. [...]

I will check it out and seed

> [zeroseed](#comment_27_1CcmrTeqtuoQtUpuxBZ9wFZz1tPaBcKb1g): i cannot seed these things. sorry but the server hosting company have my name.

I understand. You should a paid VPN in addition to TOR.

> [zeroseed](#comment_28_1CcmrTeqtuoQtUpuxBZ9wFZz1tPaBcKb1g): the server hosting company will always see what i'm seeding. Also TOR + VPN will slow the connection and will not allow an HD streaming. And i don't want to share anything illegal...i want to show how zeronet can allow internet to be better and free...not only an house for fascist and alt-right groups banned by youtube

I would suggest using a VM inside your OS to limit any sensitive information you don't want to share. Then keeping the VPN and TOR connection active inside the VM. You can choose which files you help distribute.

> [geekless](#comment_153_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4): Hi! I have a few questions... [...]

No idea. original developer is mia since 2017.
Doesn't matter as we can clone the zite. All the code is available and open. 
Take a look at the IFS cluster 0 code: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/
This is where the actual content is stored. Its very simple and easy to use. 

There are a few of us. How many are active, I'm not sure anymore, but I'm hoping to get new traction into this project.
Current status is everything is functional. There are thousands of files currently available on IFS. 
Help us seed.

1584973143_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: That's good advice. IPv6 should be disabled on any system in my opinion. Its a huge security risk.

> [sdfsdgasdew](#comment_27_1CpcxT1xWtqTRZTRR1KnH8gGsY2i4rJ7du): why is  ipv6 dangerous?

because it is often left on/up by default without protection. Its like securing your front door with IPv4 and then your backdoor IPv6 is left wide open. One of the first ways vulnerability checks to get into a system is through IPv6. And before you get on the IPv6 is great train, bear in mind that I want you to enable it so it is easier for me. So please, enable it.

> [gitcenter](#comment_1349_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): How can IPv6 be dangerous? It's just an internet protocol, like IPv4. And if you're using NAT instead of a firewall, you definitely have a serious problem.

Please, by all means, enable it. Make it easier for me to hack you.

1585933227_15cApprVFcr1skAkWssq5aAXKa7pD.body: Far easier way is to just use a separate physical pfsense firewall made from an old computer. Push all your traffic through TOR as well as through a paid VPN. No traffic should flow if not through TOR and VPN. There are hundreds of videos and guides how to do this.

> [kaaza](#comment_16_15cApprVFcr1skAkWssq5aAXKa7pDwJJve): What if I just want zeronet to go through tor? I just don't want random people seeing my IP address. I don't mind directly accessing normal websites.I could also have more than one ZeroID that I would like to keep apart from each other.
